reviewText:
An almost cutsie little game, it's so simple that you can really overthink it when you first aquire it. The goal is to get into a big blue sharp looking swirly thing (I though it was killing me when I got into it the first couple of times. turns out it's the level end portal)

There are only five things that you can do.
1. Run around (or away from ghost / scythe / Death things)
2. find collectables (gold coin things)
3. Commit suicide to provide light
4. die on obsticles and provide light
5. get into the portal (swirlly blue thing)

The only real irk that I have is in the controls... there is no delay between death and respawn, which means that if you die with your finger on the down key, you instantly respawn and are moving down, potentially to straight into a death-thing. It would be nice if there was some minor / tiny delay so that you had time to register that you'd died, and could get your finger off the trigger.

I haven't completed the game, so there may be more ways to die than those mentioned here.

So, yes / no?
um it's a kind - of Zen type game, at least the early stages have been, with unlimited lives, and every death making the next run easier. Know what you're getting into, and you'll be fine.

reviewText: You run around as a little guy in a dark room. The only source of light is you ... or rather your dead body. That's right, you have to kill yourself if you want to light your path. In each level (in classic" mode) you'll have to find a blue portal to progress to the next level.\nIn the higher levels you will also encounter traps and the "reaper".\nOptionally
date: you can try to find collectibles in the levels.\nThe game has its own achievement system
hoursPlayed: see the game's Steam discussion page) he'll consider to implement Steam achievements.\n\nBeside the "classic" mode
voteText: the game also offers the following game modes:\no Endless: Find 20 medals in a dark forest\no Heart: Not really a game mode
helpfulPercent: this takes you to the dev's website to a free game called "Sometimes You Lose Heart".\no Trust Fall: An endless falling animation. You can't kill yourself
votesHelpful:
but on yourway to the bottom you'll encounter traps.
o Chips: You're Pac-Man! ... in a dark maze.

You can basically see screenshots of each game mode on the Steam store page (except for "Heart"
votesTotal:
for obvious reasons).

Now here are my personal pros and cons:
+ Nice background music
+ Good for casual game play
+ Nice idea and concept
+ Good character handling
+ Stats and achievement pages

- Can get boring fast
- No online leader board
- No options. You can't change the resolution or play in fullscreen.

reviewText: Sometimes is a fun little game, but can get repetitious and boring after a bit. Your little alien dude runs around or away from the reaper while avoiding spinning squares/obstacles. He also needs to die often to provide light, either by self exploding( provided by you), by dying on obstacles, or the reaper. Once you reach a swirly blue portal, go in and on to the next level. There are also collectibles in the game and several game modes.\n\n
voteText: 16 of 21 people (76%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I really liked the idea of Sometimes: Success Requires Sacrifice, but ultimately the game just isn't that interesting.

Each level of the main game mode has your character in a small, brightly lit area, only able to move a short distance before encountering darkness similar to the fog of war in RTS games. The difference is that the darkness in Sometimes can only be expelled by your character committing suicide and thereby brightening up a small area of the level. This goes on until you find the exit. Later levels include moving 'traps' and the Grim Reaper, who follows you around the level, but there just wasn't enough in it to hold my interest.

Other game modes offer a bit more variation, but ultimately not enough to make the game worthy of play for more than an hour or so. I've played each of the different game types a few times, got annoyed at the game not always saving in-game achievements (there are no Steam achievements), and discovered that all in all it's just a bit boring.

It's certainly not a bad game. It's just not really anything special.

reviewText:
Sometimes is good little game. The gameplay is pretty basic; you move with WASD and suicide with spacebar.
Why suicide, you ask? The map is always dark, you being the only light source. So, when you suicide, your corpse/soul becomes another light source, making you able to see more of it.
There are 5 game modes;
Classic: Constantly suicide to comprehend obstacles and reach the checkpoint.
Endless: Suicide to see/gather medals.
Trust fall: Free fall while evading obstacles.
Chips: Dark pacman mode". Collect chips while evading ghosts.
...And heart mode
date: which I can't acess because it opens a Web Browser page that won't load.\n\nSo
recommended: would you recommend Sometimes? Usually I would say no
hoursPlayed: but considering the price tag and the nice little classical BGM
voteText: yes.\nThe suicide sound effect is irritating though.\n"

reviewText:
Baby's first gamemaker game -- Sort of.  There are 4-5 simple game( mode?)s wrapped in one here, and they all seem competently put together even if the graphics are nothing special.  Interesting idea for a mechanic, though it isn't polished enough to be fulfilling to play.  Overall, this game is more like an artist's sketchbook, than a finished piece -- probably not worth selling or buying, but very valuable practice for the author.  They should have waited, and put their next, possibly more cohesive, project up instead.

Summary of game modes:

* Classic" : Top down
recommended: press space to start level over
hoursPlayed: leaving behind a ghostly light source where you were standing.  Find the maze exit
voteText: avoiding buzz saws.  Many levels.\n* "Endless" : Top down
votesTotal: light it with ghosts.\n* "Heart" : Opens up a browser
votesFunny: to a page you can download a platformer from.  I did not download and install it.  It seems like maybe that sort of thing should be included in the actual executable steam installs..?  I may go download that (appears free?) game instead and check it out
commentsCount: at a future date.\n* "Trust Fall" : Fall through blackness
column17: go for longest fall.\n* "Chips" : Pick up collectibles in a Pacman maze."

reviewText:
I got this game for free and didn't expect it much but oh dear, turns out I love it.

The gameplay itself is very simple. You get thrown into a very dark room, to make the light and find the way you must die, but you will respawn immediately after your death. The game has 5 game modes so u can't get boring after a bit. The music is very very nice and relaxing, I like it the most. Looking at the title of the game and the gameplay, there is a message here, it's deep, isn't it?

I can definitely recommend Sometimes: Success Requires Sacrifice for the price that is currently set at ($0,99). This game does the simplicity very well. Anyway, I enjoyed it!
If I can suggest something, please add sound setup option, sometimes I just want to enjoy the background music, not the sound of the explosion.

reviewText:
I actually had a lot of fun with this game. originally bought it in a bundle then got it again on orly.

it's a puzzle game where you go through mazes in the dark, and to light the way, you use your little ghosts, which only appear when you die.

There are also quite a few different game modes, and the in-game achievements are fun but not overtly challenging.

It's a very inventive idea and the game is short 'n simple - but sweet.

The only thing i feel is missing: Steam achievements.

reviewText: You cant win this game without death. 1st success 146 sacrifices. Starting game can be plain but as level is clear, it becomes more difficult and death is inevitable. It got me more and more interested after the homing monster was introduce but it ended shortly after. Somehow it can feel like flappy bird as pressing a button a milisecond too long and you will die. This game will be great for perfectionist trying to win this game without any sacrifice but I do not see many people who will try to play more than the 1st success or endless mode like me. If you like flappy bird, you should like this game. The worst con in this game is you cant turn off the sound.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sometimes: Success Requires Sacrifice (boy that is a mouthfull) now this game, it takes alot from other games, to construct a game where you can play a copy of other games, but with it's own unique desing, and it works.

Graphics - The graphics of this game are really not that bad, are they simplicstic ? yes but are they just plain old ugly ? no. A game which ask only 1 euro or 1 dollar, depends on where you live and your currency, but what I am trying to say is, that this game, doesn't look at all bad. Could it use updated graphics ? yes, but these are enough to enjoy the game. 6/10

Music - Now here in my opinion is the strongest part of this game, the music that I have heard up to this moment, is only classical music, and mostly from a piano. Don't get me wrong, I do confess, I am a sucker for the old-timey stuff. The only part which I didn't like is that I didn't find an option to reduce sound overall. Even if you do reduce the sound from the windows volume mixer, the sound that you make when you die, stays at the same volume, which really didn't help the mood. At one moment you are listening to calming piano music and at the next when you die, you hear a blasting sound of *SHTRK*. 7/10

Cinematics and Story - None

Content - Like I already said, this game is made out of a combination of a few games, while only having one game mode, which it didn't copy. Now this isn't necessarily a bad thing, as it does include it's own spin, to not look just a plain copy and paste. It has 5 modes, which one takes you to your browser, 2 of them are copyed, one is pac-man clone and the other a game where you fall down endlessly while trying to avoid obstacles (for short: The let me try one more time type), and 2 modes which are unique. One last thing to add, is that the modes get tougher the more and more you progress through them. 6/10

Controls - Everything is fine here, the normal movement keys which are used in almost all games, a few other keys used is specific modes. The only problem I have here was with the pac-man game mode, where when you try to take a turn to enter a tight corridor, is that you get stuch hugging the wall, without really any time to correct your movement, you are dead since the ghosts catch up to you. 6/10

Gameplay - Responsive, the game is really well paced, throught any game you might try and when you get tired or had enough of dying, you still have other modes to try out. 7/10

A little game, which ask really almost nothing, but gives you a lot. Most games around this price range, rarely have that much to offer, but this one is an exception. If you do decide to give this a game try, I can assure you, that you won't regret it (as cheesy as it may sound)

Final Score: 6.4/10

reviewText:
I said I'd review it once I'd played it, so here I am doing so. I played all the modes before writing this, but it is pretty much a first imprssions review.

This looked like a very interesting concept, and overall it meets my expectations.
Simple gameplay, good as a timewaster. I would recommend it, but It doesn't quite deserve 10/10.

I like the fact that there are cards for it. I don't like the fact that there are in game achievements but not Steam achievements. Not that either strictly mean anything, and I'm not exactly an achievement junkie anyway.

There doesn't seem to be any sort of way to rebind keys, which seems like a small oversight to me. Not that there's anything wrong with WASD, but I have to either play left handed or awkwardly.

Lastly, I don't like the menu setup. Hearts" sends you to a webpage

reviewText:
I never thought that I'd find a game which would make me feel offended for having spent the cost of a Snickers bar (Marathon for those of you across the pond) on it.

Boy was I wrong.

I was having a discussion about two or three days ago with my boyfriend, about how surprisingly many game designers need to learn the difference between a challenge and a tedium.  It seems particularly poigniant right now.  The title made me think that this would be some small, clever game.  Instead, I got a game which plays like it was made in a 1000 or maybe 2000 level coding class of some kind.  The kind of game where you've been dictated that you need x, y, and z elements, but which no one in the class actually bothers to make a good and polished game out of.  This should be ad supported at best, and honestly, if I were the creator, I'd trash it and go back to the drawing board.

reviewText:
Well. 2D labyrinths are too easy. Let's do that in the dark.
- Oh, man, the player won't find the exit in the dark.
- OK... I have an idea! Let's do light by allowing the player to blow the cursor!
- Good idea, also replace the cursor by a cute little guy.
- Anyway, this is boring. How about adding collectibles?
- Sure, and achievements!
- It's still very repetitive, don't you think.
- Yes... let's price it low.

You get the point. I played for 10 minutes. Maybe the exploration gets better. I don't know, and don't want to spend time discovering it. Especially after reading the sorry guys" note about
date: maybe you will lose all your progress because of a bug.\n\nOne positive things about this computer program: music is cool. 1$ (well
recommended: technically .99) is not cheap for 10' of play.\n\n"

reviewText:
This game has a simple aspect of it, that you turn the world less dark as you die. This is a pretty cool concept, but the game gets tedious in some levels that are large and you need to die, and go back to the beginning, so you can proceed. The game is not bad, it is enjoyable, but can be boring at these times.

The mechanics are pretty simple and straightforward, which helps the game
The audio is too loud and the game does not have any option menu at all, which is a bad thing

But, the final thing that makes me recommend this game is its price. Really cheap and also way more cheap in a sale. You can have some fun time with the game. If you want to spend almost nothing in a game and still be able to enjoy it, this game can be one of those that you can go through.

reviewText: Got this game as a free gift from orly.com\nSometimes: Success Requires Sacrifice is an inteteresting little game where you are a little creature trying to find the light. It's a top down, puzzle/strategy game. In the beginning there is no light, but when you die your soul give off light to show the way. By repeated suicide you will eventually find the exit portal to the next level. As youprogress you will encounter traps and the grim reaper that will kill you. Its fun, creative and cute, but if your'e prone to rage this game ain't for you. Another thing I would change is a volume bar. It's very late and the crunching noise caused by your death has startled me multiple times. Otherwise; I you like puzzles, traps, and adorable characters (even after they die) that you would love this game.
